docs.lead_paragraph: Amid a record economic boom, janitors some of America's lowest-paid, least-visible workers -- are taking to the streets and the picket lines from coast to coast to demand a bigger share of the nation's prosperity. More than 4,000 janitors who clean office buildings in suburban Chicago have been on strike for more than a week, demonstrating downtown and blocking traffic to demand health insurance and a raise that would lift their families out of poverty.

headline.main: Janitors, Long Paid Little, Demand a Larger Slice

docs.abstract: Thousands of janitors across America take to streets and picket lines to demand bigger share of nation's prosperity; photo of janitors demonstrating in Chicago suburb of Oak Brook (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ONE of the great racial divides of traffic safety is seat belt use; young African-Americans are about 50 percent less likely than other motorists to buckle up, and they have correspondingly higher death rates in highway crashes. But safety experts are trying to build a case that new laws to increase use of belts do not conflict with another racial concern: the perception that police officers sometimes harass minority motorists, many of whom say they have been pulled over simply for ''driving while black.''

headline.main: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; Ticketing the Unbelted: Will Blacks Be Targets?

docs.abstract: Autos on Friday column on debate about how to get black motorists to use seat belts, without giving rise to charges of racial targeting; Meharry Medical School president John Maupin warns that low belt use among blacks is grave public health issue; Sec Rodney Slater, himself black, calls for 'zero tolerance' of seatbelt law violations; young blacks are 50 percent less likely as whites to use belts, and motor vehicle death rate for small children is three times as high among blacks (M)
docs.snippet: ONE of the great racial divides of traffic safety is seat belt use; young African-Americans are about 50 percent less likely than other motorists to buckle up, and they have correspondingly higher death rates in highway crashes.    But safety experts...

docs.lead_paragraph: With lavish consumer spending providing the stimulus, the American economy turned in another very robust quarter, the government reported yesterday, as new evidence emerged that prosperity is finally pushing up labor costs, raising fears of higher inflation. The inflation rate, as measured by the Commerce Department, rose to 3.2 percent in the first quarter, mainly because of higher fuel prices. But Wall Street expressed the worry that even as oil prices recede, labor costs will accelerate and keep the inflation rate rising.

headline.main: Prices Spurt 3.2% As Economy Posts Another Big Gain

docs.abstract: Commerce Dept reports that nation's gross domestic product rose at 5.4 percent annual rate in first quarter of 2000, fueled by consumer spending, and that inflation rate rose to 3.2 percent for the quarter, mainly because of higher fuel prices; Wall Street expresses worry that even as oil prices recede, labor costs will accelerate and keep inflation rate rising; Bureau of Labor Statistics' Employment Cost Index increased 1.4 percent for the quarter; chart; graph (M)
docs.snippet: With lavish consumer spending providing the stimulus, the American economy turned in another very robust quarter, the government reported yesterday, as new evidence emerged that prosperity is finally pushing up labor costs, raising fears of higher...

docs.lead_paragraph: Fresh Evidence of Growth Stokes Fear of Inflation The United States economy turned in another robust quarter, the government reported, as new evidence emerged that today's prosperity is finally pushing up labor costs, raising fear of higher inflation. The gross domestic product, representing the value of all goods and services produced in the nation, rose at a 5.4 percent annual rate. A broad inflation measure published with the G.D.P. report rose by 3.2 percent, mainly because of higher gasoline and fuel oil prices. And a measure of labor costs, the Employment Cost Index, rose 1.4 percent. [Page A1.]

docs.lead_paragraph: What a relief it was to open the newspaper on Wednesday and discover that Vice President Al Gore had given a major policy address on economic strategy to the Association for a Better New York. I say this not as a proponent or a critic of Mr. Gore's proposals, but as a Texan, and a rather chauvinistic one at that. (Is there any other kind?) For the past several weeks, most of Mr. Gore's pronouncements have focused not on national issues but on our state's deficiencies, for which his opponent, Gov. George W. Bush, is presumably to blame. Notwithstanding Mr. Gore's laudable commitment to a debt-free America, we in Texas know that the vice president will all too soon resume his efforts to persuade the American people that south of the Red River lies a callous land with the air quality of Mexico City, the health standards of Rwanda and the criminal justice system of the gulags. Worse, we suspect that the American people might just believe it.

headline.main: What a Texas Record Can't Tell

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Paul Burka, exec editor of Texas Monthly, takes exception to Vice Pres Al Gore's efforts in recent weeks to hold Texas Gov George W Bush accountable for his state's shortcomings; agrees that Texas has problems, but contends state has a conservative political culture that constrains what any governor can do; notes that Texans do not habitually look to government to solve problems; points out that Texas' governor has very little power (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna, the nation's largest health insurance company, said yesterday that its first-quarter operating profit rose 16 percent, helped by reduced losses at its Prudential Health Care unit and a rebound in international business, including financial services in Asia and Latin America. Analysts said that important challenges still remained for the company but that the results were generally positive and well above their expectations.

headline.main: Aetna's Operating Profit Rose 16% in First Quarter

docs.abstract: Aetna, nation's largest health insurance company, says its first-quarter operating profit rose 16 percent; operating earnings were $184 million, compared with $158.5 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue rose 39 percent, to $7.89 billion from $5.69 billion (M)
docs.snippet: Aetna, the nation's largest health insurance company, said yesterday that its first-quarter operating profit rose 16 percent, helped by reduced losses at its Prudential Health Care unit and a rebound in international business, including financial...

docs.lead_paragraph: William H. Donaldson is driving hard to transform Aetna, the nation's biggest health insurer, into a warm, consumer-friendly company that makes more profits and fewer enemies. In his first 60 days as chief executive, he has sidestepped fights with belligerent trial lawyers, embarked on what he calls first steps toward healing strained relations with doctors, and hired an executive search firm to find a leader for Aetna's health care business. But he is under pressure from disaffected shareholders who played a role in ousting his predecessor, Richard A. Huber, on Feb. 25. These investors want even quicker action to bolster Aetna's stock, which is languishing in the mid-$50 range after sliding 40 percent over the last year. Barring a takeover offer, which Wall Street views as unlikely, the shareholders want Aetna to sell more assets rapidly and use the proceeds to buy back shares.

headline.main: Aetna's New Chief Wants To Be Consumer-Friendly

docs.abstract: Aetna Inc chief executive William H Donaldson is driving hard to transform nation's biggest health insurer into warm, consumer-friendly company that makes more profits and fewer enemies; in his first 60 days as chief executive, he has sidestepped fights with belligerent trial lawyers, embarked on what he calls first steps toward healing strained relations with doctors, and hired executive search firm to find leader for Aetna's health care business; Donaldson is under pressure from disaffected shareholders who played role in ousting his predecessor, Richard A Huber; Donaldson says Aetna is talking with 30 business partners in 17 countries about selling some foreign units; says these assets could sell for $500 million to $1.5 billion; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Oxford Health Plans Inc. said today that its first-quarter profit beat Wall Street expectations as it left less-profitable markets and controlled its costs. Its shares rose 22 percent. Net income rose to $28.8 million, or 34 cents a diluted share, in contrast to an operating loss of $4.6 million, or 6 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier, excluding a one-time gain from the sale of its New York Medicaid business. Including that gain, net income was $14.3 million, or 4 cents a share.

headline.main: Oxford Health Earnings Rise in Quarter

docs.abstract: Oxford Health Plans Inc says first-quarter profit beat Wall Street expectations; net income rose to $28.8 milllion, compared with loss of $4.6 million a year ago; revenue fell 3.8 percent, to $1.02 billion, compared with $1.06 billion in year-earlier quarter (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: EVERY workday for the last 12 1/2 years, Melida Thomas has been going to her job at 80 Centre Street in Lower Manhattan, to the State Office of Temporary and Disability Assistance, where she is one of 15 clerical workers. In this office, which reviews city decisions about welfare and food stamp eligibility, she files, enters facts into the computer, looks up names and addresses.

headline.main: Metro Matters; Union Wins, And 15 Lose Their Jobs

docs.abstract: Joyce Purnick column on plight of 15 Hispanic clerical workers at State Office of Temporary and Disability Assistance who are about to be fired because they failed Civil Service test after their jobs were unionized; notes that they have been on job from 4 to 13 years and are considered competent workers (M)
